item.title: When Corporations Kill - Progressive Roundtable
item.description:
When Corporations Kill - Progressive Roundtable

Alex Lawson, Social Security Works & Sarah Badawi, Progressive Change Campaign Committee (PCCC) join Thom. Plus Special Panel Guest - Patty Lovera, Food & Water Watch. The Department of Justice is launching an investigation into the Dole Food company - one of the world's largest processors of fresh produce.

item.title: Guarding Against Chernobyl's Radioactive Forest Fires
item.description:
Guarding Against Chernobyl's Radioactive Forest Fires

Thirty years after the Chernobyl disaster, firefighters remain on high alert to prevent radioactive forest fires. Originally published at - http://www.rferl.org/media/video/guarding-against-chernobyls-radioactive-forest-fires/27691519.html

item.title: A Turning Point for China?
item.description:
A Turning Point for China?

In this film, William Nee discusses what it's like doing human rights work in China today, and tells the story of Pu Zhiqiang, one of China's most famous fre...

item.title: Masked Anti-Putin Protester Detained Again In Red Square
item.description:
Masked Anti-Putin Protester Detained Again In Red Square

Performance artist Roman Roslovtsev returned to Red Square to stage his latest masked protest against Russian President Vladimir Putin and a law on public ga...

item.title: India Rebuts US Charges of Deteriorating Religious Freedom
item.description:
India Rebuts US Charges of Deteriorating Religious Freedom

India has strongly rebutted charges by a U.S. Commission that religious freedom is on a "negative trajectory" in the country. The U.S. Commission on International Religious Freedom (USCIRF) recently released a report saying "religious tolerance deteriorated and religious freedom violations increased in India" in 2015.

item.title: Son of Late Philippine Dictator Maintains Appeal Ahead of National Polls
item.description:
Son of Late Philippine Dictator Maintains Appeal Ahead of National Polls

On an recent uncomfortably hot Sunday morning, Philippine Senator Ferdinand Marcos, Jr. pressed his way through a crowd at a small park along Manila Bay, shaking hands and saying thank you. It was Labor Day and Marcos, and the 57-year-old popular vice-presidential candidate who goes by the nickname "Bongbong," gave a short speech for a few hundred public sector workers.

item.title: EU Visa Block Threatens EU-Turkey Migrant Deal
item.description:
EU Visa Block Threatens EU-Turkey Migrant Deal

Turkish citizens could soon benefit from visa-free travel to Europe, as part of the deal between the EU and Ankara to stem the flow of refugees. In return, Turkey has pledged to crack down on the smugglers and keep the migrants on Turkish soil.

item.title: US, Allies Discuss Next Steps in Islamic State Fight
item.description:
US, Allies Discuss Next Steps in Islamic State Fight

The United States along with allies from 11 other countries met in Germany to discuss the joint efforts in their campaign against Islamic State.
